   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 382**] year-old female with a  history of CAD s/p MI, HTN, DM,
   hypothyrodism, depression, CVA (non-verbal at baseline) and recent
   [**Hospital1 54**] discharge for acute CHF who presents with tachypnea and
   non-responsiveness.
   .
   Plan:
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure:Patient presented with severe tachypnea
   with O2 sats in upper 80s on RA that were responsive to increased FiO2.
   Because tachypnea was not improving, patient was intubated in the ED.
   Etiology concerning for PNA as CXR finding of retrocardiac density.
   Would be hospital acquired as patient discharge day prior to admission.
   Of note, most recent admission consistent with volume overload with
   patient responding to diuresis. No evidence of volume overload on exam
   or CXR.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics for hospital-acquired PNA -
   vancomycin, cefepime
   - f/u sputum sample
   - ventilator to pressure support, wean as tolerated, vent respiratory
   bundle
   - versed and fentanyl to maintain minimal sedation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Probable source lung vs. urine. Patient just
   completed course of cephalexin for ?UTI on last admit. CXR finding,
   respiratory distress, and recent hospital admission concerning for
   hospital-aquired PNA. WBC up from discharge.
   - Broad spectrum antiobiotics for HAP
   - Follow-up blood, urine, send sputum cultures
   - Trend WBC count fever curve
   - repeat CXR after hydration
   .
   # Coffee Ground Emesis: Unclear if coffee ground emesis [**3-4**] UGI bleed
   vs. trauma from OG tube placement. GI aware and to staff patient in am.
   Patient has remained hemodynamically stable overnight. HCT stable from
   recent discharge at 39. Likely [**3-4**] NG trauma.
   - flush G tube as needed, consider removal of NG tube pending GI recs
   - pantoprazole 40mg IV BID
   - trend HCT
   - GI recs in am- unlikely need to scope given no d/c from NG tube
   .
   # Troponin Elevation: Patient with troponin of 0.11 on admission. Admit
   EKG with wider QRS but unable to assess St/T waves due to IVCD and LVH.
   - cycle enzymes
   - continue telemetry
   .
   # CHF, chronic, diastolic and systolic: EF 20-25% on [**12/2112**] echo. No
   evidence of volume overload on exam, pt appears dry w/increased
   creatinine from last admit. Patient did require 4L IVF in ED in the
   setting of hypotension surrounding intubation.
   - will hold ACE-I and spironolactone overnight, consider resuming in am
   - monitor volume status closely, consider resuming lasix in am
   - Monitor I/Os
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Baseline creatinine appears to be 1.0. Pt at 1.2
   on last discharge, 1.6 on this admit. Likely prerenal as patient
   appears dry on exam, given infectious process. Bun/Cr >20:1.
   - f/u urine lytes, follow creatinine after IVF
   .
   # Coagulopathy: Patient has had elevated INR since early [**9-8**] at 1.5.
   Was 1.4 on last admission. Unclear if related to nutritional status.
   Fibrinogen nl on admit so unlikely to be DIC. No history of chronic
   liver disease and LFTs nl on last admit, now mildly elevated on this
   admission.
   - consider trial of vitamin K
   - follow coags, monitor fibrinogen
   .
   # Elevated AST/ALT/LDH: Increased from 10 days ago. Patient with no
   previous history of liver dysfunction. Differential includes toxic
   injury from drugs vs. poor profusion. Did recently complete a course of
   valtrex for v. zoster which can cause hepatitis.
   - f/u LFSs until resolution.
   .
   # Diabetes, type 2: Appears to be diet controlled. No HbA1C in our
   system. On no oral antihyperglycemics.
   - covered with regular insulin sliding scale.
   .
   # Herpes zoster, left T7-8 dermatome:  Completed course of Valtrex on
   most recent admission.
   -Lesions have scabbed over, she does not require precautions.
   .
   # ? Seizure D/O: On Keppra from NH. Will continue.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue outpt regimen.
   .
   # Stage II decubitus pressure ulcers: sacrum and mid-back, local
   wound care continued.
   .
   # FEN: F/u nutrition recs for tube feeds
   .
   # Access: PIV  18 x2, 20 x1- patient is a difficult stick with poor
   access, will attempt PICC today
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, heparin SC, pneumoboots
   .
   # Code:  DNR, intubation OK
   .
   # Dispo:  ICU
   .
   # Comm: Family was not present on transfer to MICU. son , [**Name (NI) 5044**],
   [**Name (NI) 4874**] tel # [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5045**] work - [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5046**] confirmed DNR.

- The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure of 123/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a medical history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, hypertension, diabetes, hypothyroidism, depression, and cerebrovascular accident. She was recently discharged from the hospital for acute congestive heart failure and presented with tachypnea and non-responsiveness. She was intubated in the emergency department due to severe tachypnea and hypoxemia. The patient has been diagnosed with hypoxemic respiratory failure, possibly due to hospital-acquired pneumonia. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate set at 14 breaths per minute, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and an RSBI of 64. Her physical examination findings are not assessed for peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic responses, and movement. Lab results show an elevated white blood cell count and troponin level. The patient has several comorbidities including chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, acute renal failure, coagulopathy, elevated liver enzymes, diabetes, herpes zoster, possible seizure disorder, hypothyroidism, and stage II decubitus pressure ulcers. The plan includes continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia, obtaining sputum samples, weaning off ventilator support as tolerated, and monitoring for potential complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, upper gastrointestinal bleed

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition can be summarized as follows:

- The patient is in the ICU and has been on mechanical ventilation.
- They have a history of allergies to no known drugs.
- Antibiotics were administered on 2113-10-4 and 2113-10-6.
- The patient is receiving various medications including pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and fentanyl.
- Vital signs show a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 123/68 to 137/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%.
- The patient has a left bundle branch block (LBBB) heart rhythm.
- The patient's weight is 55.7 kg, and height is 61 inches.
- Fluid balance shows an intake of 918 mL and output of 675 mL.
- The patient is receiving nutrition through enteral feeding.
- Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, platelet count, troponin-T, and lactate levels, while other lab values are within normal ranges.
- The patient has been diagnosed with a DNR (do not resuscitate) status.

Potential medical complications that could arise based on this information include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation, the patient is at risk of developing VAP, which is a type of lung infection.

2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and the presence of central venous catheters increase the risk of developing blood clots in the deep veins, which can potentially lead to pulmonary embolism if they dislodge.

3. Stress ulcer: The use of corticosteroids and the stress of critical illness can increase the risk of developing stress ulcers in the stomach or duodenum.

4. Nosocomial infection: Prolonged hospitalization and invasive procedures increase the risk of acquiring nosocomial infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or wound infections.

5. Medication side effects: Some of the medications being administered to the patient, such as fentanyl, may have potential side effects that need to be monitored.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's condition and take appropriate measures to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure secondary to healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP). He is currently on mechanical ventilation with minimal pressure support. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 123/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient has a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), and elevated troponin levels indicating possible demand ischemia. He is also experiencing fever, leukocytosis, and a urinary tract infection (UTI).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is already on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been immobilized, which increases the risk of developing blood clots in the deep veins of the legs.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient's ICU stay and use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) increase the risk of developing stress ulcers in the stomach or duodenum.
4. Fluid overload: The patient has received a significant amount of fluid resuscitation, which may lead to fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
5. Nosocomial infection: Prolonged hospitalization and invasive procedures increase the risk of

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-inch tall and 55.7 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure secondary to healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP). The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt of 450 mL, PS of 5 cmH2O, RR set at 14, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and RSBI of 66. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 123/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%.

The patient has been receiving antibiotics for presumed pneumonia, including vancomycin and cefepime. The patient's lab results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 16.4 K/uL, elevated troponin levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and sputum gram stain shows GPC pairs/clusters and budding yeast.

The patient's physical examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally with scant right lower lobe rales, regular rhythm with a left bundle branch block (LBBB), and normal peripheral pulses. The patient's neurologic examination is not assessed.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient likely has HAP and is doing well

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual who is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU. The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, pneumonia, coffee ground emesis, demand ischemia, and diabetes mellitus (DM). They are currently receiving cefepime and vancomycin for their infections. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 101/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased potassium levels, and elevated troponin levels. The patient's renal function tests are within normal limits, but their liver function tests show some abnormalities. The patient has a central line, arterial line, and urinary catheter in place. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Since the patient is on mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP. This can be prevented by maintaining good airway hygiene and regularly assessing the patient's respiratory status.

2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's immobility due to critical illness puts them at an increased risk for developing DVT and subsequent PE. Prophylactic measures such as intermittent compression devices and

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failure secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with minimal pressure support and continues to have significant secretions and poor respiratory system compliance index (RSBI). The patient also has tachycardia/ectopy, fever, leukocytosis, decreased urine output (UOP), and elevated troponin levels. The patient has a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's current medications include vancomycin, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium. The patient is receiving IV fluids, MDI standing, and suction as needed.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable with ongoing secretions and poor RSBI despite minimal pressure support. There is an increased size in opacity in the left lower lobe (LLL) on the latest chest X-ray, indicating worsening of HAP. A bronchoscopy is planned to assess and clear the airways. If the patient does not improve or if there is further deterioration in respiratory function, extubation may not be possible.

2. Tachycardia/ectopy: The patient is experiencing intermittent ectopic beats with a heart rate above the normal range. This could be secondary to pulmonary infection, pain, hypovolemia, or other

The patient has been on minimal pressure support and continues to have significant secretions with poor respiratory system compliance index (RSBI). The patient also has a history of tachycardia/ectopy, fever, leukocytosis, decreased urinary output (UOP), coffee ground emesis, elevated troponin levels, congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), and elevated liver function tests (LFTs).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pulmonary complications: The patient's respiratory failure and HAP put him at risk for further pulmonary complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), atelectasis, and worsening gas exchange.

2. Cardiac complications: The patient has CHF, which increases the risk of cardiac complications like arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and fluid overload.

3. Infection-related complications: The patient's current infections, including HAP and possible urinary tract infection (UTI), can lead to sepsis or septic shock if not appropriately managed.

4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of coffee ground emesis may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be exacerbated by stress ulcer disease or other gastrointestinal infections.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, likely secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with minimal pressure support and continues to have significant secretions and poor respiratory system compliance index (RSBI). There is an increase in opacity in the left lower lobe (LLL) on chest X-ray and sputum culture shows gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters, indicating a possible infection.

The patient also has tachycardia and ectopy, which is suspected to be secondary to pulmonary infection, pain, and hypovolemia. There is no EKG change suggesting ischemia, so the patient will continue to be monitored for now.

The patient has fever and leukocytosis, which is being treated for presumed pneumonia and urinary tract infection (UTI). The UTI was likely exacerbated by lack of urine output. Cultures and white blood cell count (WBC) will be followed, and c.diff cultures will be obtained to rule out gastrointestinal infection.

The patient has decreased urine output (UOP), initially thought to be volume overloaded. However, over the last 48 hours, UOP has been responsive to boluses. The goal is to maintain UOP of 30cc/hr and monitor for pulmonary edema closely given the patient's low ejection fraction (EF).

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation via an endotracheal tube and is receiving IV antibiotics for both pneumonia and a urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient's troponin levels are elevated, indicating possible demand ischemia.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to HAP. The current plan is to continue minimal pressure support and reassess for extubation in the afternoon. However, no extubation is planned at this point.

2. Tachycardia/Ectopy: The patient has been experiencing tachycardia and ectopy, which may be secondary to pulmonary infection. Monitoring of heart rhythm is ongoing.

3. Fever and Leukocytosis: The patient has fever and leukocytosis, which are consistent with a diagnosis of pneumonia and UTI. The patient is currently on vancomycin and cefepime, and follow-up cultures are pending. Trending of WBC count is also recommended.

- The patient has leukocytosis, indicating a possible infection.
- The patient has a decreased urine output (UOP), which could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

- The patient shows signs of congestive heart failure (CHF), including systolic/diastolic HF.
- The patient has elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which could be secondary to liver congestion or ischemia.
- The patient is not currently receiving any hepatotoxic medications.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of non-responsiveness.
- She received an increased amount of free water through her gastrointestinal tube (GTB) and continued to receive normal saline (NS) boluses to maintain a urine output of 30cc/hr.
- The patient's C. difficile test was negative, and a bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was sent for cytology, with plans to follow up today.
- A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered to investigate the left bump and lack of urine production despite fluid boluses and free water given through the GTB.
- The patient's sputum culture showed Staphylococcus aureus coagulase positive and yeast, so vancomycin was continued, and cefepime was discontinued.
- The patient has no known drug allergies.
- She is receiving various medications, including pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and other ICU medications.
- Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.
- The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.3°F), heart rate of 76 bpm (67-82), blood pressure of 123/67 mmHg (80-136/53-91), respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute (19-35), and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air.
- The patient's fluid balance shows a total intake of 3,681 mL and output of 420 mL, with a positive balance of 3,261 mL.
- The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 400 mL and peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 25 cmH2O.
- Laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count of 16.4 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 44 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, and glucose levels ranging from 140-749 mg/dL.
- Other lab values are within normal limits.
- The patient's medical history and allergies are documented.
- The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and her disposition is noted as well.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated BUN and creatinine levels suggest possible kidney dysfunction. The lack of urine production despite fluid administration could indicate AKI, which may require further evaluation and management.

2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's sputum culture revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus coagulase positive and yeast, indicating a possible infection. VAP is a common complication in patients on mechanical ventilation for an extended period. Close monitoring for worsening respiratory symptoms and appropriate antibiotic therapy would be necessary.

3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Although not directly mentioned in the progress note, the patient is at risk for developing DVT due to prolonged immobility and mechanical ventilation. Prophylactic measures such as compression stockings or pharmacological intervention may be indicated.

4. Stress ulcer: The patient's use

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female who is currently unresponsive in the ICU. The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure likely secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), for which she is being treated with vancomycin. She also has tachycardia/ectopy, fever, leukocytosis, decreased urine output (UOP), coffee ground emesis, elevated troponin levels, congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), and elevated liver function tests (LFTs).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to HAP. If the infection spreads or if the patient's lung function deteriorates further, she may experience worsening respiratory failure, leading to potential complications such as pneumonia, sepsis, or respiratory arrest.

2. Tachycardia/ectopy: The patient's tachycardia/ectopy could be secondary to pulmonary infection, pain, hypovolemia. If left untreated or if the underlying causes worsen, it may lead to arrhythmias, decreased cardiac output, or even cardiac arrest.

3. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest an ongoing infection, which could be due to the untreated UTI or PNA. If the infection is not appropriately managed, it can progress to sepsis or septic shock, leading to multiple organ dysfunction

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient presents with non-responsiveness and has a history of respiratory failure, likely secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
- The patient is currently on minimal pressure support and continues to have significant secretions, poor respiratory system compliance index (RSBI). There is an increased size in opacity in the left lower lobe (LLL) and sputum with +GPC culture.
- Diaphoresis was noted on physical exam, raising concern for myocardial ischemia.
- Tachycardia/ectopy is believed to be secondary to pulmonary infection, pain, and hypovolemia.
- Leukocytosis is present, likely due to treating pneumonia and urinary tract infection (UTI).
- Decreased urine output (UOP) is a concern, with the patient being fluid-dependent.
- Coffee ground emesis has not recurred since transfer to the ICU.
- The patient exhibits signs of congestive heart failure (CHF), with systolic/diastolic HF observed in the last 48 hours.
- Liver function tests (LFTs) have increased drastically, possibly due to liver congestion or ischemia.
- Fluid balance is closely monitored with daily weights and strict input/output (I/O) measurements.
- The patient's goals of care will be discussed with the family, and weaning from the ventilator is a priority.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Complications:
   - Prolonged

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of CVA (non-verbal at baseline) who is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia. She remains intubated and has been difficult to wean from the ventilator. The patient is non-verbal and unable to provide further history.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is likely experiencing acute respiratory failure due to pneumonia. This is a serious condition that requires immediate medical intervention.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which is an infection in the lungs. This can lead to worsening respiratory symptoms and potentially progress to sepsis if left untreated.
3. Oliguria: The patient's urine output is difficult to discern, indicating potential oliguria. Oliguria can be a sign of inadequate renal function or fluid imbalance, which needs to be closely monitored and managed.
4. Difficulty Weaning from Ventilator: The patient has been difficult to wean from the ventilator, indicating a potential complication in the process of extubation. This increases the risk of post-extubation complications such as airway obstruction, respiratory distress, or infection.
5. Dementia: The patient has underlying dementia, which may affect her ability to communicate and respond to medical interventions. This could complicate the assessment and management of her condition.
6. Code Status: The patient has a DNR (do not resuscitate) code status,

   Assessment and Plan
   #Respiratory failure/CHF exacerbation: Patient now extubated and on
   vancomycin [**6-8**]. Patient with very low central SVO2 and PO2. Since
   patient with cold extremities, low urinary output, known EF of 15% and
   very low central venous PO2, then most likely etiology is a low cardiac
   output.
   -continue vancomycin Day [**5-9**]
   -suction as needed, MDI standing
   -ABGs in the afternoon
   -f/u CXR
   -Start dobutamine low dose
   #Decreased UOP: Patient with very low UOP during last 24 hours
   (<500cc). Most likely cause is low cardiac output. Will maximize CHF
   treatment
   -bolus 250cc NS as needed
   -Control BP (<140/90)
   -Dobutamine
   # Leukocytosis: Treating PNA and UTI. At this point has been covered

The patient's vital signs show hypothermia, tachycardia, hypertension, and tachypnea. The patient has been extubated but required reintubation due to respiratory failure. The patient's urine output has been low, leading to concerns about possible pulmonary edema. The patient also exhibits diaphoresis, leukocytosis, and evidence of congestive heart failure (CHF) with systolic/diastolic dysfunction. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus (DM) and elevated liver function tests (LFTs) without any identified cause. The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, and heparin sodium for prophylaxis. The patient has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) code status and requires discussion regarding goals of care with the family, with a focus on weaning from the ventilator first.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial presentation of non-responsiveness and subsequent respiratory failure indicates a high risk for further respiratory complications. Continued monitoring and intervention will be necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's low urine output and fluid status raise concerns about the development

The patient has been receiving dobutamine, antibiotics, and other medications.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who presented with non-responsiveness. The patient has a history of decreased urine output, cold and clammy extremities, and poor oxygen saturation. The patient was intubated and received mechanical ventilation. Blood cultures were obtained to rule out sepsis. The patient is currently on vancomycin and meropenem for suspected pneumonia and urinary tract infection. The patient's condition has not improved, with persistent fever, low urine output, and elevated white blood cell count. The patient also has elevated liver function tests, but no clear cause has been identified. The patient's cardiac function is compromised, with an estimated ejection fraction of 15%. The patient is being treated with dobutamine to improve cardiac output. The patient's nutritional needs are being met through tube feeds. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: Given the patient's low ejection fraction and symptoms of poor perfusion (cold extremities, low urine output), cardiogenic shock is a potential complication.
2. Sepsis: The presence of fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood cultures suggests an ongoing infection, which could lead to sepsis if not promptly treated.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's decreased urine output and elevated creatinine levels indicate a possible kidney injury.
4. Hepatic Dysfunction: Although the liver function tests are elevated, no specific cause has been identified. Further investigation is needed to determine

The patient's blood cultures are positive, indicating an ongoing infection.

Summary:

The patient required reintubation due to respiratory distress caused by pneumonia not covered with vancomycin alone. Meropenem was added to treat the pneumonia. The patient also has decreased UOP, likely due to low cardiac output, and is being treated for CHF. There is leukocytosis, likely secondary to a treated UTI and ongoing PNA. The patient's LFTs are elevated but trending down, and no cause has been found. The patient's nutrition is being provided through tube feeds, and repletion of electrolytes is ongoing. The patient has a PICC line in place, and prophylaxis is being given for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP. The patient's code status is DNR, and weaning from the vent is the first step in disposition.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial presentation and subsequent reintubation indicate ongoing respiratory failure. This could be due to worsening pneumonia or exacerbation of CHF.
2. Decreased UOP: The patient's low urine output may indicate low cardiac output, possibly exacerbated by CHF treatment.
3. Leukocytosis: Although the UTI has been treated, the patient remains febrile and has leukocytosis. Ongoing infection or other causes should be considered.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and CHF exacerbation. He was re-intubated due to respiratory distress caused by pneumonia not covered with vancomycin alone. Meropenem was added to treat the infection. The patient also has decreased urine output, likely due to low cardiac output. He has leukocytosis and has been treated for pneumonia and UTI with cefepime. Elevated liver function tests are being monitored without any identified cause. The patient's code status is DNR.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial presentation included respiratory failure, which required re-intubation. It is crucial to closely monitor his oxygenation and ventilation parameters, ensuring optimal settings on the ventilator and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
2. CHF Exacerbation: The patient's CHF may contribute to respiratory failure and should be managed accordingly. Monitoring fluid balance, cardiac function, and administering appropriate diuretics or other CHF medications is essential.
3. Pneumonia: Despite receiving vancomycin, the patient developed pneumonia. Monitoring for any signs of worsening infection or antibiotic resistance is necessary. Adjusting antibiotic therapy if needed and ensuring proper source control are important.
4. Decreased Urine Output: The patient's low urine output needs to be evaluated and managed promptly. Assessing renal function, correcting fluid imbalances, and optimizing cardiac output are important steps to consider.
5. Leukocytosis: Treating the underlying infections and monitoring the patient's white blood cell count and fever curve are essential. Following up on cultures and trend analysis will help determine the effectiveness of the current treatment plan.
6. Elevated Liver Function Tests: Monitoring liver function tests and identifying the cause of elevation is important. Adjusting medications if hepatotoxicity is suspected and continuing to trend LFTs will provide valuable information for patient management.
7. Malnutrition: Considering the patient's prolonged ICU stay and inability to eat orally, ensuring adequate nutritional support is crucial. Tube feeds have been initiated, and nutritional goals should be discussed with the family and healthcare team.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: Repleting electrolytes as needed is important to maintain electrolyte balance and prevent complications such as cardiac arrhythmias.
9. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) Prophylaxis: Heparin prophylaxis should be continued to prevent DVT, a common complication in critically ill patients.
10. Ventilator-associated Pneumonia (VAP): Implementing strategies to prevent VAP, such as proper oral hygiene, elevation of the head of bed, and regular lung secretion clearance, are important to reduce the risk of developing this complication.

The patient is receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis and pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the prolonged duration of mechanical ventilation.

3. Stress ulcers due to the use of corticosteroids and sepsis.

The patient's labs show elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, and troponin T levels. His kidney function is impaired with elevated creatinine levels. Other lab results are within normal range.

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP.

3. Stress ulcer: Prolonged critical illness and use of corticosteroids can lead to stress ulcers.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and CHF exacerbation. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 113/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on FiO2 50%. The patient's physical examination reveals clear lung fields with scant rhonchi, soft and non-distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds, and cool extremities with 1+ pulses but no rashes or edema. 

The patient has been receiving various medications such as furosemide, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium. She has also been given antibiotics including vancomycin and meropenem. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.6 K/uL, normal hemoglobin and platelet levels, elevated troponin-T levels, and elevated lactate levels. The patient's electrolytes are within normal range except for slightly low potassium and magnesium levels. 

The patient's renal function tests indicate a creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL. Her liver function tests are within normal limits. The patient's glucose levels have been stable without the need for insulin. 

The patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-inch, 65.4 kg individual admitted to the ICU. They have been receiving various medications, including lasix, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/59 to 133/79 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, set at a peak inspiratory pressure of 16 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen at 50%. The patient's ABG results show pH of 7.20, PaCO2 of 20 mmHg, and PaO2 of 100 mmHg. The patient has a radial pulse but has not been assessed for distal pulses or skin condition. Neurologic examination is also not assessed.

Lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, and normal platelet count. Kidney function appears to be within normal range based on creatinine levels. Troponin-T levels are within normal limits, but there are some abnormalities in liver function tests (ALT/AST and alkaline phosphatase) and electrolyte levels (potassium and phosphorus).

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube and receiving various medications, including lasix, protonix, and heparin. The patient's vital signs show a stable temperature, slightly low blood pressure, normal heart rate, and respiratory rate. The patient has gained weight since admission. Fluid balance is positive, with a total intake of 3,227 mL and output of 650 mL. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. There are also abnormalities in kidney function and electrolyte levels. The patient's cardiac biomarkers are within normal range. The patient's condition remains unchanged since admission.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, some potential medical complications that can arise for this patient include:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given that the patient is on mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP. Monitoring for symptoms such as fever, increased sputum production, and changes in oxygenation may be necessary.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of DVT. Regular assessment of peripheral pulses and surveillance for symptoms such as leg swelling or pain may be needed.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-inch tall and 65.4 kg male who was admitted with acute respiratory failure and pneumonia. He is currently receiving CPAP support and has improved urine output with the use of lasix. The patient has a history of being non-verbal at baseline and is now unresponsive. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4 C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 108/55 to 129/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's heart rhythm is a first-degree AV block. He has shown improvement in his fluid balance and is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube. The patient is also on prophylactic antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and stress ulcer prophylaxis. His code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and he will continue to receive ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving CPAP support, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory symptoms and sputum culture analysis should be done to detect any changes in lung infection.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to immobility and central venous catheter placement. Regular assessment of peripheral pulses and consideration of prophylactic anticoagulation should be

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, pneumonia, and a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation through CPAP mode.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's current condition include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is already diagnosed with pneumonia, and being on mechanical ventilation increases the risk of developing VAP.

2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobility and critical illness are risk factors for developing DVT. Prophylactic measures should be in place to reduce this risk.

3. Stress ulcer: Critical illness and the use of certain medications can increase the risk of stress ulcers. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like pantoprazole are often used for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

4. Complications related to the CVA: The patient has a pre-existing CVA, which may lead to neurological deficits. There is a risk of further neurological deterioration or other complications associated with the CVA.

5. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels have been fluctuating, indicating possible renal insufficiency. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is essential.

6. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure readings show low values, indicating hypotension. This could be due to sepsis or other underlying conditions. Appropriate

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female who is currently unresponsive and admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of non-responsiveness. She has a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) with a low ejection fraction of 15%, diabetes mellitus (DM), and is on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient is receiving lasix for decreased urine output, antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and diuretics for CHF exacerbation. She has copious secretions that may impair extubation today. Family meeting will be held to assess goals of care. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of further respiratory deterioration if extubation fails or if there is a worsening of underlying conditions such as CHF or HAP.

2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Being on mechanical ventilation for an extended period increases the risk of developing VAP. The patient is already receiving antibiotics, but regular follow-up and cultures are needed to monitor for any changes or progression of infection.

3. CHF Exacerbation: The patient's low ejection fraction and current negative fluid balance indicate a high risk for further CHF exacerbation. Close monitoring and management of fluid balance, along with ongoing treatment for CHF, are necessary.

   Ca++:7.7 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:2.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   #Respiratory failure: Most likely HAP and CHF exacerbation. Patient on
   antibiotics and active diursesis. Mental status has never been an issue
   for extubation, but her baseline is not-responsive. However, right now
   patient with copious secretions that could impair us from extubating
   her today. Family meeting today to assess goals of care. Currently on
   [**6-5**] and FiO2 of 0.4 with RR 24 and tidal of ~300cc.
   -Continue Vanc/Meropenem to complete 10-day course.
   -Manage CHF and negative balance as goal today
   -f/u CXR in am
   -suction PRN
   -MDI standing
   #CHF: Low EF (~15%) on carvedilol and lisinopril at home, which have
   been held.
   -Continue ASA
   -Start carvedilol 6.5mg
   -pressors if pressure drops
   #Decreased UOP: Responded to lasix 20IV x1, HD stable.
   -lasix 20mg IV x1
   -Control BP (<140/90)
   # VAP: Continue to follow fever curve and WBC. Patient with GPC on BAL
   , 10 day course of vanco, meropenem.
   -f/u cultures
   -trend WBC
   -vancomycin, meropenem (now [**4-10**])
   #DM: patient has been normoglycemic without need for insulin over
   several days.
   -restarted SSI for FS 200s
   #FEN: continue tube feeds per nutrition recommendations, free water
   bolus per Gtube (decrease today to 250 q8hrs), replete electrolytes as
   needed
   -kayexelate for rising K

   MICU ATTENDING ADDENDUM
   I reviewed pertinent history and lab data and examined patient.  I was
   physically present with the MICU team during the key portions of the
   service provided.  I agree with the note above, including the
   assessment and plan. I would add and emphasize the following:
   I had the chance to talk to her son, [**Name (NI) 4874**], at some length today.  The
   patient has been able to communicate somewhat, both by speech and
   hearing, despite being in a wheelchair, hard of hearing and blind at
   her N.H.  Her son, her proxy, believes that the patient enjoys life
   still enough to want to continue fighting, even to the point of a
   tracheostomy if necessary.  Two yrs ago the pt was intubated for 2
   weeks but was ultimately extubated.  She remains a DNR, and son would
   not want dialsysis if renal failure were to supervene.  He describes
   his mother as not someone to give up.
   On exam: vital signs stable. On vent: PSV 5/5 40% VT= 300
   Patient non responsive.  Lungs clear though ETT secretions still a
   problem. [**Name (NI) 59**] JVD. Cor RRR. Abd- G tube, old zoster lesions.  She
s under
   a bear hugger for prior hypotension
   Lab: CBC and lytes as above.  Creat down to .8   Vanc = 21  CXR
   suggests LLL infiltrate
   Problems:
   1.       [**Name2 (NI) **] CVA dementia, chronic
   2.       LLL pneumonia
   3.       CAD and CHF with EF =20%
   4.       Renal Insufficiency
   5.       Dispo: DNR but not DNI
   Plan:
   1.       Make I/O 500 cc neg daily
   2.       Continue Vanc, Meropenem
   3.       Restart Coreg for CHF
   4.       Resume free H20
   5.       Once secretions less of a problem and she
s a bit more
   diuresed, then I
d try another extubation attempt and if she fails,
   proceed to trache.
   Patient Critically ill.  Time spent=35 min plus 25min family mtg =
   60min total

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female admitted to the ICU with non-responsiveness. She has a history of CVA dementia, chronic, LLL pneumonia, CAD and CHF with an EF of 20%, renal insufficiency, and DNR status but not DNI. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has copious secretions, which may impair extubation. Her family desires to continue fighting and pursue aggressive measures, including tracheostomy if necessary. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she remains unresponsive. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
2. Heart failure exacerbation
3. Acute kidney injury
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
5. Stress ulcer bleeding
6. Ventilator-induced lung injury
7. Tracheostomy-related complications

Please note that this is a summary of the provided information, and additional details may be necessary for a comprehensive analysis.

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypothyroidism. She presented with respiratory failure and is currently intubated in the ICU. The patient's family has discussed goals of care, including the possibility of intubation with the goal of extubation if successful. If extubation fails, they would like to proceed with tracheostomy. The patient was restarted on carvedilol for heart failure, initially on 6.25 mg and then reduced to 3.125 mg due to low blood pressure. Vancomycin levels were measured and found to be 21, so vancomycin was held. The patient received 10 IV Lasix yesterday evening for decreased urine output.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to being intubated for an extended period. Close monitoring of fever curve and white blood cell count is recommended. The patient has already been placed on antibiotics and active diuresis to manage this risk.
2. Chronic heart failure exacerbation: The patient's low ejection fraction (EF) of 15% indicates a higher risk for CHF exacerbation. Management includes continuing medications such as carvedilol and monitoring fluid balance. Diuretics may be necessary to manage fluid overload.
3. Decreased urine output

The patient is on multiple medications, including carvedilol for heart failure, and antibiotics for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia. She has also received IV lasix for decreased urine output.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently dependent on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of worsening respiratory function and the possibility of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

2. Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP): The patient's respiratory culture showed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus, which indicates a possible HAP. Treatment with appropriate antibiotics is crucial to prevent further complications.

3. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) Exacerbation: The patient has a history of CHF, and her current condition may be exacerbated due to fluid overload or medication non-compliance. Monitoring and managing her fluid balance, along with optimizing her heart failure medications, is important to prevent further deterioration.

4. Decreased Urine Output: The patient's urine output needs to be closely monitored, as she received IV lasix to

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She presented with respiratory failure and is currently intubated in the ICU. The family has agreed to proceed with intubation with the goal of extubation, and if unsuccessful, tracheostomy. The patient is on multiple medications, including carvedilol for heart failure, which was restarted at a lower dose due to low blood pressure. Vancomycin levels were monitored, and the medication was held when it reached 21. The patient received IV lasix for decreased urine output. Her vital signs are stable, but she has a first-degree AV block. The patient's laboratory results indicate some abnormalities, including elevated lactate levels, low albumin, and abnormal liver function tests. The assessment suggests that the patient's respiratory failure is likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation. The plan includes continuing antibiotics, managing CHF, and attempting to wean off the ventilator once secretions improve. Other concerns include decreased urine output, hypertension, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has a do not resuscitate (DNR) code status and will be kept in the ICU until extubated or until a tracheostomy is performed.

Potential medical complications:
1. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP): The patient

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of CAD, s/p MI, DM, hypothyroidism, who presented with respiratory failure. The patient has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation. She has been diagnosed with HAP (hospital-acquired pneumonia) and CHF exacerbation. The patient's family wants to proceed with extubation if possible, and if unsuccessful, they consent to tracheostomy. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen if she is not successfully extubated.
2. Pneumonia: The presence of bilateral lower lobe opacities on the chest X-ray suggests bilateral pneumonias, which could lead to further respiratory complications.
3. Heart Failure: The patient's low ejection fraction (LVEF 25%) indicates a weakened heart, increasing the risk of heart failure exacerbation.
4. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's decreased urine output may indicate renal insufficiency, which could be exacerbated by medications or underlying conditions.
5. Infection: The presence of yeast in the urine culture may indicate a urinary tract infection, which could spread and cause systemic complications.
6. Dementia: The patient's history of dementia could affect her ability to respond appropriately after extubation.
7. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and decreased venous return due to mechanical ventilation

She has a left bundle branch block (LBBB) on EKG and is receiving antibiotics for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 116/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on FiO2 50%. The patient's weight has increased from 55.7 kg at admission to 66.5 kg currently.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 13.6, slightly elevated creatinine levels, and normal electrolytes. Troponin-T levels have decreased from 0.04 to 0.02. Other lab values are

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure exacerbation and hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) suspected to be caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The patient has been receiving antibiotics (vancomycin and meropenem) and diuretics. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 36.4°C
- Heart rate: 84 bpm
- Blood pressure: 116/56 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 98% on CPAP/PSV ventilation

The patient's physical examination reveals a left bundle branch block (LBBB) on ECG. The patient's current weight is 66.5 kg, and her admission weight was 55.7 kg. 

Laboratory results show:
- White blood cell count: 13.6 K/uL
- Hematocrit: 36.4%
- Platelet count: 245 K/uL
- Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
- Blood urea nitrogen: 36 mg/dL
- Glucose: 88 mg/dL
- Sodium: 135 mEq/L
- Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L
- Chloride: 107 mEq/L
- Carbon dioxide: 18 mmHg
- Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
- Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
- Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
- Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
- Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
- Respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.24

The patient's respiratory cultures showed no microorganisms seen, but the oropharyngeal flora absent culture revealed Staphylococcus aureus coag positive, with 10,000-100,000 organisms/mL. The yeast count was approximately 1000/mL. 

The patient's plan includes continuing vancomycin and meropenem until the end of the 10-day course, managing congestive heart failure (CHF) with diuretics, suctioning per rectum as needed, and weaning off the ventilator if there is improvement in secretions. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to HAP and CHF exacerbation. If the patient does not respond to treatment or if the secretions continue to be a problem, there is a risk of further deterioration in respiratory function.
2. Infection: The patient has already shown evidence of bacterial infection with Staphylococcus aureus. There is a risk of developing additional infections, especially if the patient is immunocompromised or if proper infection control measures are not maintained.
3. Fluid overload: The patient's history of CHF and current management with diuretics indicate a risk of fluid overload. Monitoring fluid balance and adjusting diuretic dosages will be important to prevent fluid overload.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels need to be monitored closely, especially sodium, potassium

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) and respiratory failure. She has been admitted to the ICU for acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's initial presentation included decreased responsiveness and diaphoresis, leading to suspicion of an infectious insult causing respiratory decompensation in the setting of known impaired cardiac function.

The patient has been on prolonged ventilatory support for 12 days, with a recent attempt at extubation that failed due to volume overload and the development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Currently, the patient is showing minimal response to verbal commands but does have a documented cuff leak on examination. A chest X-ray shows persistence of left lower lobe consolidation.

The plan moving forward includes:
- Extubation in the morning
- Continuing antibiotic therapy (vancomycin and meropenem) until October 22nd for a 10-day course for VAP
- Maintaining a negative fluid balance
- Transitioning to CPAP support rapidly post-extubation, with management of edema
- Considering a tracheostomy for long-term support if reintubation is needed

The patient also has a diagnosis of congestive heart failure, for which she is receiving medications such as Coreg, Lasix, and spironolactone. Good rate-pressure product control will be important during extubation.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of non-responsiveness. He was previously intubated but extubated yesterday morning and is currently on a shovel mask with 5L O2, maintaining an oxygen saturation of 94-98%. The patient has been experiencing periods of apnea and desaturation into the high 70s, which resolve on their own. Vital signs include a heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure of 115/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.3 C. The patient is alert and oriented, with no acute distress. Physical examination reveals wheezes on lung auscultation, mild muscle wasting, and no spontaneous movement. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit, and elevated troponin T levels. The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure due to suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) MRSA and congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation. Antibiotics (vancomycin and meropenem) have been initiated, and diuresis is being continued. The family prefers the patient to have a tracheostomy if extubation fails. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's current respiratory failure may worsen if there is a delay in treating the suspected HAP MRSA or if the CHF exacerbation progresses.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with non-responsiveness. The patient has been intubated and placed on invasive ventilation but was extubated yesterday morning. He is currently on a shovel mask with 5L O2 and has an SpO2 of 94-98%. The patient has been experiencing periods of apnea and desats into the high 70s, which resolve on their own. His vital signs include a heart rate of 120-80s bpm, blood pressure ranging from 115/61-127/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 (10-34) inspiratory minutes, and an oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient has a history of left bundle branch block and has gained weight from 55.7 kg at admission to 66.5 kg currently. 

The patient's medications include vancomycin, meropenem, pantoprazole (Protonix), heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and furosemide (Lasix). The patient has allergies to no known drugs. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below. 

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, thin appearance, pale conjunctiva, right endotropia, normocephalic head, poor dentition, symmetric chest expansion, resonant percussion, mild expiratory wheezes, soft non-tender abdomen

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of non-responsiveness. She has a history of pneumonia, severe systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), and is currently on invasive ventilation. The patient was extubated yesterday morning and is now on a shovel mask with 5L O2, maintaining an oxygen saturation of 94-98%. She has been clearing her throat and coughing occasionally but appears comfortable with vital signs of 120/80s, 80s. The patient has had periods of apnea and desaturation into the high 70s, which resolve on their own, during which her hemodynamics remain stable. She was written for 20mg IV lasix at 5am.

The patient has no known drug allergies. She has been receiving various medications including vancomycin, meropenem, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and furosemide. Her review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.

Flowsheet data shows the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and other relevant information. The patient's weight has increased from 55.7 kg at admission to 66.5 kg currently. Her urine output has been low at 1.1 L yesterday.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and troponin T levels, but otherwise within normal limits. Imaging studies are mentioned but not explicitly described

The patient, a 90-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, was admitted with respiratory failure. She has successfully been extubated without any complications. She has a left bundle branch block and has gained weight since admission, now weighing 66.5 kg compared to her admission weight of 55.7 kg. 

The patient is receiving various medications including furosemide, lansoprazole, heparin sodium, and prophylactic antibiotics (vancomycin and meropenem). Her fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total intake of 940 mL and output of 1113 mL since 12 AM. The patient is on invasive ventilation support, using a face tent to deliver oxygen, and her ABG results indicate hypoxemia. 

Her lab results show normal hemoglobin, leukocyte count, and platelet count, but there are some abnormalities in her kidney function tests (creatinine) and electrolyte levels (potassium, sodium).    respiration, although a component of hydrostatic edema is possible.

   5. Excessive tracheal collapsibility, suggesting tracheomalacia, but
   incompletely evaluated.

The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. She has been admitted to the ICU with a history of HAP MRSA, exacerbating significant systolic/diastolic CHF. The patient initially improved with diuresis but is now not responding as well. She experiences desaturation with minimal movement and has apneic periods. Her current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 126/73 to 133/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on high flow nasal cannula.

Other lab values indicate elevated troponin-T levels, decreased platelet count (265 K/uL), and abnormal liver function tests.

Summary: The patient is a 63-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypotension, oliguria, and acute kidney injury. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On admission, he was hypotensive and oliguric with elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. He required aggressive fluid resuscitation and vasopressors for blood pressure control. Despite this, he continued to have persistent hypotension and oliguria, leading to the diagnosis of acute kidney injury. The patient's condition has been complicated by multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), including respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation and cardiac dysfunction evidenced by left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient also has elevated pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (proBNP) levels, which suggest cardiac stress. Additionally, the patient has been experiencing severe sepsis with positive blood cultures for both vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) and multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (MDRPA). He has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem, as well as antifungal therapy with caspofungin. Despite these interventions, the patient's condition remains critical, and he continues to require aggressive management in the ICU.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old female with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. She has a history of HAP MRSA, exacerbating significant systolic/diastolic CHF. The patient initially improved with diuretics but is now not responding well. She experiences desaturation with minimal movement and has an increased need for supplemental oxygen. The CT chest shows increased bilateral pleural effusions, collapse of the left lung with obstruction of the left main stem bronchus, ground-glass opacity in the right lung, increased ascites, diffuse anasarca, excessive tracheal collapsibility, cardiomegaly, atherosclerotic calcifications, osteopenia, and a 1-cm nodule adjacent to the spleen. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she is on high-flow nasal cannula for respiratory support. The patient has several medical conditions including respiratory failure, CHF, diarrhea, decreased urine output, and diabetes mellitus.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure due to mucus plugging and lung collapse. There is a risk of further deterioration in respiratory function if the mucus plugging is not effectively managed.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's systolic/diastolic CHF may lead to cardiogenic shock, especially if the heart function continues to deteriorate.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of HAP

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with respiratory failure and underwent extubation but returned with hypoxemia. She is currently on high flow nasal cannula with FiO2 of 0.8 and ABG showing pH of 7.48, PaCO2 of 26, PaO2 of 51, and oxygen saturation of 90%. Her proBNP level is 70K and did not respond well to Lasix overnight. Cardiac enzymes are negative.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 110/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 90%. She has a left bundle branch block heart rhythm. Her weight is 66.5 kg, and she has received a total of 283 mL of IV fluids since midnight, with a balance of -197 mL. She is on high flow nasal cannula for respiratory support.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 13.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, platelet count of 265 K/uL, sodium level of 142 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L, creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL,

Summary:
The patient is a 91-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. The source of the respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, including pleural effusion, aspiration, and multilobar pneumonia with collapse. The patient has responded well to supportive care, including chest physical therapy (PT) and suctioning.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.7°C, a heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 111/70 to 129/82 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on a nasal cannula. The patient has a left bundle branch block (LBBB) heart rhythm. The patient's weight is currently 66.5 kg, with an admission weight of 63.9 kg.

The patient's fluid balance shows a total input of 1,401 mL and a total output of 780 mL, resulting in a positive fluid balance of 621 mL. The patient is receiving various medications, including heparin sodium, furosemide (Lasix), and others.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count ranging from 8.7 to 13.3 K/uL, hemoglobin level ranging from 34.8% to 39.9%, platelet count ranging from 61 to 145 K/uL, creatinine level ranging from 0.8 to 1.2 mg/dL, troponin T level ranging from 0.02 to 0.03 mg/dL, glucose level ranging from 86 to 172 mg/dL, and other lab values within normal range.

Imaging shows improved aeration bilaterally. The patient's assessment and plan include acute respiratory failure with a likely multifactorial source, as well as congestive heart failure. The patient is currently on Lasix 40mg/d to maintain a mild negative fluid balance, and chest PT and suctioning are essential for maintaining open airways and secretion clearance. The patient's congestive heart failure will require up titration of treatment, including carvedilol, spironolactone, and ASA.

The patient is on full nutrition with fiber and regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control. The patient has a PICC line in place and is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and her disposition is to be transferred to the floor.
